entry.title: Ghostscript: a proper tool for pdf compression

link.title: Ghostscript: a proper tool for pdf compression

entry.content:
Many people come across the problem of pdf compression. In this situation, it is possible to compress it on one’s own computer using a number of different software packages, or browse the web and find online services to perform this task. They are usually known as SaaS, Software as a Service. In this post, I would like to present an existing software package called Ghostscript, that can be used to compress pdf files locally on one’s own computer. It is simple, easy to use, and provides excellent outputs.


First of all, let me introduce this package. Ghostscript is a cross-platform suite of softwares that has a version under the GNU GPL licence. It can handle Postscript and PDF formats. This package can be downloaded in the official website. Compressing a pdf is as easy as opening a terminal, browsing to the original pdf folder using cd, and running the following command

  • under Windows (adjust the path to the executable):
"C:\Program Files\gs\gs9.02\bin\gswin32c.exe" -q -dSAFER -dNOPAUSE -dBATCH -sDEVICE=pdfwrite -dPDFSETTINGS=/Parameter -sOUTPUTFILE=OutputFile.pdf -f InputFile.pdf
  • under Mac OS:
/usr/local/bin/gs -q -dSAFER -dNOPAUSE -dBATCH -sDEVICE=pdfwrite -dPDFSETTINGS=/Parameter -sOUTPUTFILE=OutputFile.pdf -f InputFile.pdf
  • under GNU/Linux:
gs -q -dSAFER -dNOPAUSE -dBATCH -sDEVICE=pdfwrite -dPDFSETTINGS=/Parameter -sOUTPUTFILE=OutputFile.pdf -f InputFile.pdf

Parameter can be adjusted depending on the compression level that you wish. ebook is usually a good compromise. Here are the different options:

  • /screen selects low-resolution output similar to the Acrobat Distiller “Screen Optimized” setting.
  • /ebook selects medium-resolution output similar to the Acrobat Distiller “eBook” setting.
  • /printer selects output similar to the Acrobat Distiller “Print Optimized” setting.
  • /prepress selects output similar to Acrobat Distiller “Prepress Optimized” setting.
  • /default selects output intended to be useful across a wide variety of uses, possibly at the expense of a larger output file.
